p: Protein content of flour from both varieties ranged from 15.6–19.6 g/100 g DW using a factor of 5.7 to convert nitrogen to protein. In previous studies 6.5 was used [ 23, 38]. The general use of 6.25 as N:P conversion factor is criticised because this disregards variations in non-protein nitrogen and variable percentages of nitrogen in individual proteins [ 38]. Yet the protein content of raw BG in this study is in line with the 17.8–19.7 g/100 g DW [ 34, 39], but lower than the 25 g/100 g reported by Brough, Azam-AIi [ 40]. The protein content of the flour of the red variety was significantly higher than that of the black-eye variety (p = 0.00), implying that choice of variety matters [ 35]. Moreover, pre-treatments significantly increased the protein content of flour of both varieties (p = 0.001).
